Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Andrew Zuza of University of California at Los Angeles to conduct a research project in Geoscience during the summer of 2013 at Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences in Beijing, China. The project title is "Tectonic Development of the Tibetan Plateau: Insights from the Qilian Shan Thrust Belt." The host scientist is Professor Rui Gao.

Determining the Cenozoic evolution of Qilian Shan thrust belt, along the northern edge of the Tibetan Plateau, is fundamental in understanding how continental deformation and shortening induced by the India-Eurasia collision is accommodated across the plateau. This research investigates the structural framework, fault geometries, and Cenozoic shortening magnitude of the Qilian Shan thrust belt by systemically mapping a transect of the thrust belt. This surface geology is being compared with high-resolution seismic-reflection data recently obtained by the SinoProbe Project in order to see how mapped surface structures continue at depth. Furthermore, this work involves mapping active faults that are responsible for producing large (momentum magnitude scale greater or equal to 8) earthquakes. Increased knowledge regarding these faults is valuable for evaluating the seismic hazards associated with these structures.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved investigating the Cenozoic evolution of Qilian Shan thrust belt, along the northern edge of the Tibetan Plateau, which is fundamental in understanding how continental deformation and shortening induced by the India-Eurasia collision is accommodated across the plateau.  By systematically mapping a transect of this thrust belt, the project sought to constrain the structural framework and magnitude of strain accumulation that the margin of the plateau has experienced in the Cenozoic. The project has led to the development of a detailed geologic map, which includes important fault geometries and kinematics, as well as balanced cross sections. Preliminary reconstructions indicate that the region experienced approximately 45% Cenozoic shortening strain. While further verification is needed, this suggests that a significant portion of the > 2500 km of convergence between India and Eurasia may have been accommodated in this region.

Important active faults, which were previously only inferred, were identified and mapped. These faults link with major intraconinental structures that are responsible for producing large (M>8) earthquakes. Increased knowledge regarding these faults will valuable for evaluating the seismic hazards associated with these structures.

Lastly, the graduate student Fellow conducted research with Chinese researchers and professors, and was able to gain first-hand experience working with and observing an important rising scientific power in the world. Collaborations and partnerships were formed and developed, which will foster continued joint research efforts as well as an internationally aware scientific workforce.
